repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Northeast Emergency Irrigated
            Agriculture Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Northeast Emergency
            Irrigated Agriculture Project for Sri Lanka were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was un-evaluable, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            lending for land-based assets in a protracted conflict
            affected situation, characterized by massive displacement,
            and should be sequenced within a broader social development
            framework that balances individual needs with equity aims.
            The term ‘post-conflict’ should be used sparingly in the
            absence of a negotiated peace agreement and World Bank
            projects should accordingly exercise caution in project
            design in situations where conflict may re-emerge. There is
            a tension between responding to the immediate needs of
            conflict affected populations and the use of a community
            driven development model to respond to these needs in fluid
            or highly mobile environments. Participatory development is
            a process that should be nurtured and supported throughout
            all stages of a project cycle.

Sri Lanka - Northeast Emergency Irrigated

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - Restoring livelihoods in
            conflict zones

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            restoring livelihoods in conflict zones of Sri Lanka. Sri
            Lanka’s 30 year war between the government and the
            Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam devastated nearly
            two-thirds of the population of its Northern and Eastern
            provinces. People could no longer access markets as they
            once had and the transport of goods virtually came to a
            halt. The International Development Association financed the
            Reawakening Project to adopt a community-driven development
            approach. Over 500 villages in the conflict-affected areas
            have been organized into community-based institutions and
            were benefiting from new community and productive
            infrastructure. More than 35,000 hectares of irrigated land
            has been brought back to cultivation through the
            rehabilitation of seven major irrigation schemes that had
            been damaged by the conflict, benefiting more than 55,000
            farm households. Over 10,000 small community groups started
            saving schemes, developed their business plans, and accessed
            credit to upgrade the vocational and life skills for jobs
            and to set up micro-enterprises.

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - North-East Irrigated
            Agricultural Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the North-East Irrigated
            Agricultural Project for Sri Lanka was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            project: Delivering assistance directly to communities and
            forming strategic alliances between key stakeholders are
            critical determinants of project success in conflict
            affected situations. Anchoring a project at the provincial
            level in Sri Lanka increases ownership at the local level
            and facilitates project implementation. Innovation and
            flexibility in project design, initial piloting of project
            activities, and close and competent supervision, are
            important if projects are prepared quickly in conflict
            affected situations. In a conflict situation securing
            technical assistance to build local capacity is critical.
            Selecting villages in poorer areas and activities targeted
            to poor and landless people, ensure benefits of
            irrigation-led projects reach communities and families most
            in need of assistance. Livelihood support to women's
            groups can make a project more inclusive and has tremendous
            potential for alleviating poverty. Community Based
            Organizations (CBOs) need sufficient training and technical
            back-up to sustain project created assets. Continuous
            monitoring and assessing of project processes and impact
            with beneficiary participation, should be part of project
            monitoring and evaluation and MIS systems. It is not
            sufficient to have technical auditing without a clearly
            defined practical quality management system in place.

repnme.cdata!:
Sri Lanka - North East Irrigated
            Agriculture Project (NEIAP) : environmental management framework

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment for the
            Sri Lanka North East Irrigated Agriculture Project
            anticipates negative environmental impacts and proposes
            measures to mitigate them. The project repairs small
            irrigation schemes and rural roads, and builds community
            buildings and drinking water wells. To reduce accelerated
            soil erosion, restrict construction to the dry season,
            retain ground vegetation, retain channel/drainage
            reservation, turf exposed surfaces quickly, and create
            contour strips/steps as slope breakers. To prevent water
            logging and flooding, rehabilitate borrow areas, reshape
            excavated areas, and design proper drainage. Retain ground
            cover to reduce soil erosion, dump vegetation and scraped
            earth at suitable location and compact, and avoid clogging
            natural drainages. Use a clay cut off wall and ruble packing
            and toe filler to stem seepage. Retain natural vegetation
            and avoid cutting large trees. Mobilize community to prevent
            encroachment, fires, and tree cutting in catchment areas.
            Control dust by water and cover excavated soil material
            during transport. Train farmers in water management,
            conservation agriculture, organic farming, and integrated
            pest management. Create awareness of proper handling,
            storage, and disposal of pesticides and insecticides. Locate
            wells away from agricultural lands and drainages, dumping
            grounds, latrines, and saline deposits to prevent
            groundwater contamination from runoff and salinization.

display_title.display_title:
Sri Lanka - North East Irrigated
            Agriculture Project (NEIAP) : environmental management
            framework : Environmental management framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The North East Irrigated Agriculture
            Project (NEIAP), backed by $27 million from the World Bank,
            has enabled farmers to return to their fields and increase
            the amount of irrigated land by 2,900 hectares benefiting
            about 4,700 families. The project has supported the
            rehabilitation of 61 kilometers of roads and has provided
            225 wells brimming with clean drinking water. More than
            100,000 poor people are expected to benefit from the project
            by the time of its completion in 2005.
